awd_titl_txt: Partial Differential Equations in Several Complex Variables
awd_abstract_narration:
Complex analysis in one and several variables plays a special role in mathematics and mathematical physics.  The use of complex numbers has been essential in the development of mathematics.  Partial differential equations and several complex variables are employed in string theory and twistor theory, physical theories that try to unify different physical force fields.  The existence and regularity of solutions to such partial differential equations are still not fully understood, and they form some of the most challenging problems in mathematical analysis.  The current study is not only important for the development of mathematics, but it may lead to new understanding of physical phenomena as well, with potential applications in other sciences and technology.  

This research focuses on some of the most important equations in several complex variables, the Cauchy-Riemann equations and the induced tangential Cauchy-Riemann equations.  The topics investigated in this research project include function theory on complex manifolds, Hausdorff property of Dolbeault cohomology groups, Levi-flat hypersurfaces and complex foliation, and the Cauchy-Riemann operators on complex projective spaces and negatively curved manifolds.  Understanding the geometric aspects of these equations under the curvature conditions and their relations with function theory in complex manifolds is a challenging and important problem.  New approaches have been introduced to study these problems which connect the topology of domains in complex manifolds with the topology of Dolbeault cohomology groups.  The study of several complex variables in a geometric setting has provided interesting new questions with fresh insight to problems in topology, foliation theory, complex dynamics, algebraic and complex geometry.  This project aims to deepen understanding in this area.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
The project concerns several questions in several complex variables using the method of partial differential equations. In one and several complex variables, the Cauchy-Riemann equations play central role. The major goal of the project is to understand these equations in the setting of complex manifolds.

While these problems are well understood in the complex Euclidean spaces or Stein manifolds in the past century, much less is known when the complex manifold is not Stein and has a curvature condition. The P.I. and her collaborators have a systematic plan to understand these problems using powerful tools from other branches of mathematics, including harmonic analysis, geometric measure theory, algebraic and differential geometry. Using the Hilbert space approach and the Serre duality in the Sobolev setting, several precise results including the Hausdorff property of the Dolbeault cohomology, the Runges approximation theorem in several variables, function theory on non-smooth domains and complex projective manifolds have been obtained. They also provide new insight and methods to tackle the more difficult problems. The P.I. and her collaborators aim to establish a coherent theory in understanding the Cauchy-Riemann equations and related problems on non-smooth domains or in complex manifolds.

The P.I. is also engaging in writing a graduate textbook tentatively entitled "An Introduction to Complex Analysis in One Complex Variable". The book is intended as a prequel of her other book in several complex variables. The goal of the book is to introduce more students to study complex analysis using modern approach, including Hilbert space techniques to function theory on Riemann surfaces. The book will certainly have broader impact in terms of educating a new generation of complex analysts.


Last Modified: 10/13/2021
Modified by: Mei-Chi Shaw
